title: Blake Harrison: ‘The Dunkirk evacuation wouldn’t happen today… the country is just so polarised’
text:
Eight decades ago this month, Britain was beginning to feel the painful realities of the Second World War. Only a few weeks after the conflict started, two large ships – HMS Courageous and HMS Royal Oak – had already been lost at a cost of more than a thousand lives. The first bomb had landed in the UK, at Hoy in the Orkney Islands. And while the first soldier killed in action was still two months away, by the end of October, all men aged between 20 and 23 were required to register for conscription.

Blake Harrison has been thinking a lot about what it must have been like to be a young man in those days. He’s now 34, but when he was in that age bracket for a call-up, more than a decade ago, he...
